awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical abstract: 
Recent discovery of high-temperature superconductivity in iron pnictides has initiated a new era in condensed matter physics, significantly expanding quantum materials research. The understanding of fundamental principles of light-matter interaction in iron-based superconductors on femto- pico- and nanosecond time scales contributes to new insight into the origin of High-T superconductivity. From a technological point of view, this knowledge is important for revolutionary applications of all-solid-state optical systems outside the laboratory because of their ruggedness, efficiency, compact size and ease of maintenance. The goal of this research is to obtain new information about transient dynamics of quasiparticles and nonequilibrium phases, carrier redistribution and relaxation, and ultrafast manipulation of electronic and structural order in iron-based superconductors. This knowledge is critical to build all-optical devices based on novel optical phenomena, and to create high-speed optoelectronic superconducting Q-bits which can operate at relatively high temperatures, above ~20 K. This project has significant institutional impact enhancing interdisciplinary advanced-level training for graduate and undergraduate Hispanic STEM students and postdoctoral researchers. The research activity integrates a broad spectrum of scientific, outreach and technical experiences, and most of the research is the part of the student/postdoctoral training on their ways to careers in academia and industry.

Technical abstract: 
This project pursues experiments to elucidate the evolution of nonequilibrium phases of iron-based quantum materials, which is critical for understanding of fundamental dynamical processes of superconductivity upon photoexcitation. A variety of powerful femtosecond laser pump-probe spectroscopy techniques are applied to create and characterize novel quantum phases, quasiparticle relaxation and the electron-boson interactions. Methods of ultrafast optics provide stimulation and selective probing of specific degrees of freedom in solids in order to visualize multidimensional nonequilibrium dynamics on the timescale of lattice vibrations and to reveal dynamics of spontaneously broken symmetries, to elucidate hidden phases and features of light-induced suppression/creation of the superconducting state and to provide new insights into "intertwined" order parameters on ultrashort time scales. Real-time imaging of nonequilibrium dynamics across broad length and time scales can provide important information about the scales over which spin wave functions are coherent. To answer fundamental questions about the size-dependent quantum material dynamics, a novel time- and angle-resolved hemispherical light scattering method is applied. This technique visualizes angular distribution of scattered light at cryogenic temperatures to monitor transient nonequilibrium processes in grains/domains of different size. The fabrication of iron-based superconducting epitaxial films is based on new pulsed laser deposition protocols developed during the project.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project yields deep insights into fundamental processes in Fe-based superconductors  (FBS) at fundamental timescales and elucidates the evolution of excited states dynamics upon photoexcitation.

Our results demonstrate that the Cooper pair formation starts at temperatures significantly above Tc, where the electron-electron thermalization time τee increases as the temperature drops below a value that exceeds onset temperatures Tconset. This rise in τee correlates with reduced electron-electron scattering due to pairing. Observed electron dynamics can be used to refine existing theories of superconductivity and could lead to the development of new theoretical frameworks. 

It was shown that the transient photoinduced reflectivity dynamics of FeSe1-xTex  and  Ba(Fe0.92Co0.08)2As2 superconductors have distinct nematic responses in superconducting (SC) state, in a normal state, and at the structural phase transition point, indicating strong electronic correlations. The study of transient and steady-state nematicity provided new insights into different types of phase transitions in FeSe1-xTex: This study reveals significant changes in the electronic and lattice contributions to the transient reflectivity signal near the temperature of the orthorhombic-tetragonal structural transition.  By correlating nematicity and electronic interactions in FBSs, it could be possible to identify key features of superconductors to engineer superconductors with tailored properties.

It was shown that the optical response and nematicity of FeSe and  FeSe0.8Te0.2 are highly sensitive to pump fluence and polarization, revealing that nematic order is primarily electronic, with minimal phononic contributions. Anisotropic nematic pathways emphasize the role of directional electronic correlations. Strong directional dependence of nematicity can be applied to control electronic pathways in quantum, electronic, and optoelectronic devices. Demonstrated polarization-sensitive dynamics can help design novel optical devices, optimized for specific material responses.

The work provides new insights into the complex interplay between optical nonlinearities, structural phase transition, electronic correlations, electron-phonon energy transfer, and the second moment of Eliashberg function in FeSe1-xTex and Ba(Fe0.92Co0.08)2As2. The evolution of the second moment of the Eliashberg function reveals a complex interplay between electronic correlations, electron-phonon coupling, density of states, and optical nonlinearity. For FeSe1-xTex superconductors was shown that the electron-phonon coupling constant λ has enhancement as the temperature approaches Tconset, suggesting increased coupling strength critical for superconducting transition. The observed temperature- and pump-fluence-dependent behavior of electron-phonon and electron-electron interactions is key for the controlled manipulation of electron-phonon interactions and structural phases in FBSs. This knowledge is critical for the understanding of the λ enhancement near Tc and potentially can be used to find a pathway to engineer materials with stronger coupling and, therefore, increased Tc.

It was shown that the surface morphology and structural transitions alter electronic and phonon dynamics, with significant surface reconstruction observed in light scattering experiments.

Novel angle-resolved hemispherical light scattering measurements at cryogenic temperatures reveal alteration of optical properties, conoscopy patterns, and surface autocorrelation length in the Low-T region, below ~30 K, along with superconducting transition, indicating noticeable alteration of the electronic density of states that correlates with lattice distortion in both, FeSe1-xTex  and  Ba(Fe0.92Co0.08)2As2 superconductors. Moreover, phonon spectra of photoexcited  FeSe1-xTex correlate with structural and superconducting transitions, showing strong coupling between lattice distortions and electronic properties. The understanding of surface reconstruction and its correlation with superconducting transition can be used to improve the fabrication of thin-film superconductors with better uniformity and stability. The understanding of the nature of lattice distortions vs electronic properties can help to employ strain engineering to enhance superconducting properties, enabling customizable devices for various industrial applications.

For all FBSs, we revealed very specific and complex optical nonlinearities that depend on temperature and excitation pump energy. These nonlinearities could be highly promising for ultrafast communication technologies in quantum or neuromorphic circuits, frequency converters, optical limiters, and wavelength-selective devices, where femtosecond-level optical switching or modulation is required, along with significantly reduced heat generation and energy losses.

This project made a significant impact on the professional development of postdoctoral researchers, and graduate and undergraduate students, providing excellent training for numerous STEM students at the University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez, and also stimulated the foundation of the first OPTICA Student Chapter in Puerto Rico. Through participation in various OPTICA activities, students not only amplified their own knowledge and skills but also amplified the reputation of the laboratory's research program. It is noteworthy that these skill sets have direct implications in the field of Quantum Materials Science, positioning them for competitive career paths in academia and industry. Students acquired unique skills in condensed matter physics, quantum materials, physical optics, nonlinear optics, ultrafast optics, and diffraction. This experience allows them to continue their career in universities or National Laboratories.
